</td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Today part of</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Alpes Maritimae</b> (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">Latin pronunciation:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="la-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Latin" title="Help:IPA/Latin">[ˈaɫpeːs<span class="wrap"> </span>maˈrɪtɪmae̯]</a></span>; English: 'Maritime Alps') was a small <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">province</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> founded in 63 AD by <a href="/wiki/Nero" title="Nero">Nero</a>. It was one of the three provinces straddling the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> between modern <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, along with the <a href="/wiki/Alpes_Graiae_et_Poeninae" title="Alpes Graiae et Poeninae">Alpes Graiae et Poeninae</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alpes_Cottiae" title="Alpes Cottiae">Alpes Cottiae</a>. The Alpes Maritimae included parts of the present-day French departments of <a href="/wiki/Alpes-Maritimes" title="Alpes-Maritimes">Alpes-Maritimes</a> (in which the name survives), <a href="/wiki/Alpes-de-Haute-Provence" title="Alpes-de-Haute-Provence">Alpes-de-Haute-Provence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hautes-Alpes" title="Hautes-Alpes">Hautes-Alpes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The capital of the province was <a href="/wiki/Cemenelum" class="mw-redirect" title="Cemenelum">Cemenelum</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Cimiez" title="Cimiez">Cimiez</a>, a neighbourhood of <a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a>), until it was replaced by Eburodunum (modern <a href="/wiki/Embrun,_Hautes-Alpes" title="Embrun, Hautes-Alpes">Embrun</a>) during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a> (284–305).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpes_Maritimae&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: History"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ar%C3%A8nes_de_Cimiez,_Nice,_France.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ar%C3%A8nes_de_Cimiez%2C_Nice%2C_France.jpg/250px-Ar%C3%A8nes_de_Cimiez%2C_Nice%2C_France.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ar%C3%A8nes_de_Cimiez%2C_Nice%2C_France.jpg/500px-Ar%C3%A8nes_de_Cimiez%2C_Nice%2C_France.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5760" data-file-height="3840"></a><figcaption>The Roman amphitheatre of Cemenelum</figcaption></figure> 
<p>Following the subjugation of the local <a href="/wiki/Ligures" title="Ligures">Ligurian</a> tribes in the summer of 14 BC, the region was ruled by a <i>praefectus civitatium</i>, then was given <a href="/wiki/Latin_Rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin Rights">Latin Rights</a> in 63 AD and placed under the administration of a <i><a href="/wiki/Procurator_(ancient_Rome)" title="Procurator (ancient Rome)">procurator</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Cemenelum" class="mw-redirect" title="Cemenelum">Cemenelum</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Cimiez" title="Cimiez">Cimiez</a>), the chief town of the <a href="/wiki/Vediantii" title="Vediantii">Vediantii</a>, became the capital of the new province.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Under <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a> (284–305), the province was extended via the incorporation of parts of <a href="/wiki/Gallia_Narbonensis" title="Gallia Narbonensis">Gallia Narbonensis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alpes_Cottiae" title="Alpes Cottiae">Alpes Cottiae</a>, and was allocated to the <i>praefectura Galliarum</i> (<a href="/wiki/Septem_Provinciae" title="Septem Provinciae">Diocese of Vienne</a>). The capital was transferred to Eburodunum (modern <a href="/wiki/Embrun,_Hautes-Alpes" title="Embrun, Hautes-Alpes">Embrun</a>), which had been part of the <a href="/wiki/Alpes_Cottiae" title="Alpes Cottiae">Alpes Cottiae</a> until that time.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraßl2006-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Settlements">Settlements</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpes_Maritimae&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Settlements"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Major settlements within the province included:
</p>
<ul><li><i>Cemenelum</i> (<a href="/wiki/Cimiez" title="Cimiez">Cimiez</a>)</li>
<li><i>Nicaea</i> (<a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a>)</li>
<li><i>Antipolis</i> (<a href="/wiki/Antibes" title="Antibes">Antibes</a>)</li>
<li><i>Portus Herculis Monoeci</i> (<a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a>)</li>
<li><i>Salinae</i> (<a href="/wiki/Castellane" title="Castellane">Castellane</a>)</li>
<li><i>Sanitium</i> (<a href="/wiki/Senez" title="Senez">Senez</a>)</li>
<li><i>Vintium</i> (<a href="/wiki/Vence" title="Vence">Vence</a>)</li></ul>
<p>After 297 the province was expanded to include:
</p>
<ul><li><i>Ebrodunum</i> (<a href="/wiki/Embrun,_Hautes-Alpes" title="Embrun, Hautes-Alpes">Embrun</a>)</li>
<li><i>Brigantio</i> (<a href="/wiki/Brian%C3%A7on" title="Briançon">Briançon</a>)</li>
<li><i>Brigomagus</i> (<a href="/wiki/Brian%C3%A7onnet" title="Briançonnet">Briançonnet</a>)</li>
<li><i>Civitas Rigomagensium / Rigomagus</i> (<a href="/wiki/Chorges" title="Chorges">Chorges</a>)</li></ul>

style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">History</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">As found in the <i><a href="/wiki/Notitia_Dignitatum" title="Notitia Dignitatum">Notitia Dignitatum</a></i>. Provincial administration reformed and <a href="/wiki/Roman_diocese" title="Roman diocese">dioceses</a> established by <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 293. Permanent <a href="/wiki/Praetorian_prefecture" title="Praetorian prefecture">praetorian prefectures</a> established after the death of <a href="/wiki/Constantine_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine I">Constantine I</a>. Empire permanently partitioned after 395. Exarchates of <a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna" title="Exarchate of Ravenna">Ravenna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Africa" title="Exarchate of Africa">Africa</a> established after 584. After massive territorial losses in the 7th century, the remaining provinces were superseded by the <a href="/wiki/Theme_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Theme system">theme system</a> in c. 640–660, although in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Asia Minor</a> and parts of Greece they survived under the themes until the early 9th century.</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr hidden="until-found"><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible uncollapsed navbox-subgroup mw-made-collapsible" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2"><button type="button" class="mw-collapsible-toggle mw-collapsible-toggle-default" aria-expanded="true" tabindex="0"><span class="mw-collapsible-text">hide</span></button><div id="Western_Roman_Empire_(395–476)660" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> (395–476)</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;line-height:1.2em;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Praetorian_prefecture_of_Gaul" title="Praetorian prefecture of Gaul">Praetorian prefecture<br>of Gaul</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Gaul" title="Diocese of Gaul">Diocese of Gaul</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Not to be confused with Alpes-Maritimes, the modern département of France.
Province of Alpes Maritimae
Provincia Alpes Maritimæ

Province of the Roman Empire
63 AD–476

The Roman Empire c. 125 AD, with the province of Alpes Maritimae highlighted.
Capital	Cemenelum (63 AD – 297 AD)
Ebrodunum (from 297 AD)

Historical era	Antiquity


• Established by Nero
	63 AD

• Disestablished
	476



	Succeeded by
	
Kingdom of Italy (476-493)	

Today part of	France Monaco

The Alpes Maritimae (Latin pronunciation: [ˈaɫpeːs maˈrɪtɪmae̯]; English: 'Maritime Alps') was a small province of the Roman Empire founded in 63 AD by Nero. It was one of the three provinces straddling the Alps between modern France and Italy, along with the Alpes Graiae et Poeninae and Alpes Cottiae. The Alpes Maritimae included parts of the present-day French departments of Alpes-Maritimes (in which the name survives), Alpes-de-Haute-Provence and Hautes-Alpes.[1]

The capital of the province was Cemenelum (modern Cimiez, a neighbourhood of Nice), until it was replaced by Eburodunum (modern Embrun) during the reign of Diocletian (284–305).[2]

History[edit]
The Roman amphitheatre of Cemenelum

Following the subjugation of the local Ligurian tribes in the summer of 14 BC, the region was ruled by a praefectus civitatium, then was given Latin Rights in 63 AD and placed under the administration of a procurator. Cemenelum (modern Cimiez), the chief town of the Vediantii, became the capital of the new province.[2]

Under Diocletian (284–305), the province was extended via the incorporation of parts of Gallia Narbonensis and Alpes Cottiae, and was allocated to the praefectura Galliarum (Diocese of Vienne). The capital was transferred to Eburodunum (modern Embrun), which had been part of the Alpes Cottiae until that time.[2]

Settlements[edit]

Major settlements within the province included:

Cemenelum (Cimiez)
Nicaea (Nice)
Antipolis (Antibes)
Portus Herculis Monoeci (Monaco)
Salinae (Castellane)
Sanitium (Senez)
Vintium (Vence)

After 297 the province was expanded to include:

Ebrodunum (Embrun)
Brigantio (Briançon)
Brigomagus (Briançonnet)
Civitas Rigomagensium / Rigomagus (Chorges)

Late Roman and early Byzantine provinces (4th–7th centuries AD)


hide
History


As found in the Notitia Dignitatum. Provincial administration reformed and dioceses established by Diocletian, c. 293. Permanent praetorian prefectures established after the death of Constantine I. Empire permanently partitioned after 395. Exarchates of Ravenna and Africa established after 584. After massive territorial losses in the 7th century, the remaining provinces were superseded by the theme system in c. 640–660, although in Asia Minor and parts of Greece they survived under the themes until the early 9th century.
